title: Period of SHM - claim about pendulum period

content.question: A pendulum undergoes simple harmonic motion with period <math alttext="T" display="inline" overflow="scroll"><mi>T</mi></math> after being displaced by a small angle <math alttext="delta theta" display="inline" overflow="scroll"><mtext>Δ</mtext><mi>θ</mi></math> and then released from rest. A student claims that if the pendulum is displaced by an angle <math alttext="the fraction delta theta over 2" display="inline" overflow="scroll"><mfrac><mrow><mtext>Δ</mtext><mi>θ</mi></mrow><mn>2</mn></mfrac></math>, it will oscillate with period <math alttext="the fraction T over 2" display="inline" overflow="scroll"><mfrac><mi>T</mi><mn>2</mn></mfrac></math>. Is the student’s claim correct? Why or why not?

choices.label: Yes, because the amplitude of the pendulum’s oscillation will be smaller.
Yes, because the period is proportional to the angular displacement.
No, because for small angles the period of an object undergoing simple harmonic motion does not depend on the amplitude of oscillation.
No, because the pendulum will have a smaller average speed, so will take longer to complete a full oscillation.

content.answer: No, because for small angles the period of an object undergoing simple harmonic motion does not depend on the amplitude of oscillation.

skill.text: 3.C: Justify or support a claim using evidence from experimental data, physical representations, or physical principles or laws.
